Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of Fundamental rights. V. S. Mani, for the petitioner.

The relevant part of Art. 370 with which we are concerned is in these words- Notwithstanding anything in this Constitution,- (d) such of the other provisions of this Constitution shall apply in relation to that State  i.e., the State of Jammu and Kashmir  subject to such exceptions and modifications as the President may by order specify. Article 370 clearly recognises the special position of the State of Jammu and Kashmir

anchor.surface_text: under Art. 32, we are of opinion that there is no force in it. The relevant part of Art. 370 with which we are concerned is in these words- Notwithstanding anything in this Constitution,-

arguments.claim: Art. 370 gives President power to apply other provisions to J&K subject to exceptions and modifications as he may by order specify; power includes excepting provisions entirely or applying with modifications

anchor.surface_text: The relevant part of Art. 370 with which we are concerned is in these words- Notwithstanding anything in this Constitution,- (d) such of the other provisions of this Constitution shall apply in relation to that State  i.e., the State of Jammu and Kashmir  subject to such exceptions and modifications as the President may by order specify.

arguments.claim: Modification prescribes indirect election in place of direct election; President nominates on recommendation of elected Legislature which involves voting; element of election remains though indirect

anchor.surface_text: Now in form the seats will be filled by nomination by the President but in reality what the modification provides is indirect election in place of direct election to these seats in the House of the People. The modification lays down that the President will nominate

arguments.claim: Even assuming introduction of indirect election is radical alteration, such modification is justified by word 'modification' in Art. 370(1); Constitution not to be interpreted narrowly

anchor.surface_text: the question still remains whether such a modification is justified by the word modification as used in Art. 370(1). We are here dealing with the provision of a Constitution which cannot be interpreted in any narrow or pedantic sense

arguments.claim: In re Delhi Laws Act observations apply to delegation context for subordinate legislation, not to Art. 370 which recognizes special position of J&K and gives wide power to President

anchor.surface_text: The question that came for consideration in In re Delhi Laws Act case was with respect to the power of delegation to a subordinate authority in making subordinate legislation. It was in that context that the observations were made

arguments.claim: Power to make exceptions under Art. 370 implies President can efface provisions entirely; thus power to modify must be in widest amplitude including to amend provisions for application to J&K

anchor.surface_text: We have already pointed out that the power to make exceptions implies that the President can provide that a particular provision of the Constitution would not apply to that State. If therefore the power is given to the President to efface

arguments.claim: Word 'modify' in Art. 370 includes amendment; dictionary meaning includes partial changes, alter without radical transformation, but also to vary, extend, enlarge; in law means to limit, restrict, vary

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that when the Constitution used the word modification in Art. 370(1) the intention was that the President would have the power to amend the provisions of the Constitution if he so thought fit in their application

arguments.claim: President had the power to make the modification which he did in Art. 81 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the President had the power to make the modification which he did in Art. 81 of the Constitution.

holdings.text: observations in In re Delhi Laws Act not applicable to Art.370 context
